message_text: Yea if some controlled medication helps with the depression and that is what is being suggested to you through your treatment, then it seems apt to follow through with that. Why'd you skip all of your classes though? Motivation or pain? Haha nice snake game is a fun game. Classic. Yea I think there needs to be a balance between livelihood and doing what you love. Unless a person is 100% committed to X job they love and has nothing else in their life really...doing what you love without thought to the livelihood isn't really easy to do. For me, work is a means to an end...I work such that I can provide for my family and do the things, like in our Karya, that I actually want to spend time doing. So I'll look for the opportunities that allow for that. Engineering is a classical example of that being there. I worry for people who go through college, which is expensive, and major in something that doesn't pay out for them because the debt and all the stuff that goes along with it can easily make it a very difficult life to live regardless if you do what you love. For me, education, spirituality, religion, etc are things that I love but I've found means to express and do something with it outside of it being my job. I teach Sanskrit on the weekends. I am involved in our Karya. I read and meditate every single day without fail...these outlets help me feel fulfilled.
context_prev: 526110|me|We're actually gonna get together at Swapnil's with all the youth so should be a lot of fun || 526285|me|How bout you?
context_next: 526011|them|Haha nice that's awesome. We're having some people over at our place! So it should be a lot of fun haha || 525605|me|Yeah exactly, so I'll see what the doc says and go from there. It was a combination, motivation cause I just didn't wanna make myself go cause I saw no reason. But also physically I do need to be sleeping earlier at least days I have 9am class. I slept for 3 more hours and I def felt better. But the sleep is motivation and how I feel so ig it comes back to that. But yesterday and today I've done everything and more then I would have thought, even though it hurts a lot sometimes. It's just the hope that it will get better, but it's in the back of my head that it just isn't gonna last, cause whenever it hurts I just wanna stop. But I haven't yet so that's good. Yeah, so that's kind of how I saw cs when I chose. For the time and money I'd spend to what I get it would be the best bang for your buck. And it's a means to an end, like you've found these different things to give your life meaning and fulfillment. But since like probably April/may ive questioned that, cause medicine is exciting, in a different way then CS. Kind of like the feeling I get from chess, actual curiosity. But I'm not really sure where that balance should be drawn. I definitely need to explore more what options there are doing something health related in cs and even in health there's so much available. At the same time though I feel like a lot of it might just be in the state of mind that I'm in right now. Just anxiety and worry even though I might not always feel like that. So have to take it with a grain of salt. What have you read lately? And that's great that'll be fun. Gotta watch the niners win
gold_notes: teaches Sanskrit on weekends; works in engineering; reads and meditates daily

message_text:
First, attached to this email is the Event Waiver for non-college participants. This document needs to be completed and turned in individually by anyone under the age of 18 or anyone not affiliated with a university. Note that participants playing on a club team from another university (ex. a participant above the age of 18 from TCU) would not have to fill out the waiver. 

Additionally, we need the Captain's Packet for the weekend and a schedule of events for the weekend. This schedule should detail approximately what time each game will start. These documents can be emailed to compsports@utdallas.edu. 

We also wanted to give you more information about tents, chairs, and tables. Regarding tents, Woof will have access to one UREC tent to be used as you all please. We will also be providing two additional tents to shade the water provided by the training staff. Please send us a count of how many tables and chairs you all will need for this weekend so that we can work on moving those sites out to the shed. 

Finally, Woof is scheduled for a shopping spree with Noah tomorrow. Please remember that all items given out to teams must be pre-packaged and boxed up for each team beforehand for food safety reasons.

message_text:
Haha that's interesting. What race is he?

Haha na not at all. These chintans at demo aren't part of universal format. It seems that people are kinda doing what they can for their own area and there's not much national guidance for it. So was just curious. But that's pretty long for sure haha.

Yea so there's a practice in meditation that's popular right now called mindfulness. That's kind of what you're talking about. The idea is to feel everything and experience everything with a lot of attention and consciousness....ergo you feel more intensely the negative things but that also helps to dissolve it quicker. I would also say that I perceive the ability to do something broken up into two parts: what you can do + external forces. You can't control the latter. So no reason to dwell on the idea that the world can throw stuff at you...because you don't and never will control it. But you can also say that with 100% accuracy that you not trying will absolutely mean that you won't achieve anything. So always keep working at it!

Yeaaa I think taking it slowly is a good thing but if there are exercises that help you feel better, of course those should be done.

Haha yea that's basically it. We work requirements a lot for the missile defense system. So what the system should do and how we get it done and then verifying that we actually did do that.

That's good it's going well and it's the stuff you're able to do now. Yeaa I think that makes sense at a certain level, we also go towards the path of (apparent) least resistance. And you have been out of it for a while...give yourself some time to reset your mind and all that. And then your habits will kick back in and hopefully help eradicate the idea that you don't want to do it anymore. Are you able to do any of the exercises at home? Haha yea we'll definitely come. We came last year during the summer. Not sure what the plan would be this year but hopefully sooner than later! Yeaaa it has been busy. Right now I'm just muscling my way through everything, just making myself do it even though I don't feel like it, and it works short term. But life throws stuff at you and then it might not work anymore, which happened to me. But the better solution would be to understand how I feel and change that, much much harder and scary because it probably would involve feeling worse, but that's something to work towards. I am, there mostly just with bands or body weight, I just don't do them. Or even cardio. I should be but I don't want to. Ohh that's interesting. Shaking my head would hurt my head. I get like really strong headaches because of motion sickness and shaking my head would definitely trigger it lol.
Oh man that's unfortunate. Well one other way of potentially mapping progress could be to see how long it takes for this sort of pain, vertigo, sensitivity to light comes back. Meaning if last year, it'd come back once a week, and now it comes back once every 3 months, then that's still progress. Even though the immediate shows that you have to wait it out until you feel better, the frequency at which that happens has lessened which is good. And beyond that, I could imagine things would be worse off if you didn't do anything so definitely keep that motivation up bro. It's necessary.

message_text: I have mixed feelings. Like the Mavs really started to turn it around when they had at least two of Luka, Dinwiddie, Brunson on the floor. Brunson honestly plays like a mini Luka.  Both are methodical drivers who use shiftiness and strength to get to their spots and score/pass. Dinwiddie on the other hand brings another element. He makes really quick decisions, whether is a quick drive after a catch on the weak side, quick swing pass, or burst out of the triple threat. It’s nice to have that dynamic next to the deliberate and methodical Luka. Plus the second year after the ACL injury is when guys usually start to look like themselves again. I think the biggest weakness is the second unit right now. There is talk of Wood coming of the bench to start, and that might be enough to boost them, especially with the return of THJ. But I wouldn’t be surprised if another move was made to get another piece

message_text: So personally I think PER is outdated. It’s not really a good indicator of what the league values right now. Teams value floor spacing, shot creation, and defense. PER doesn’t adequately measure any of those. I also use player tracking data, instead of just box score data. This makes a big difference, especially when it comes to perimeter defense. Traditional stats primarily rely on steal/block numbers. I look at things like how many times you actually contest a shot, how the opponent gets worse when you match up with them, etc.
context_prev: 544234|me|Oh wow that’s really interesting, don’t they already have PeR and stuff like that || 544036|me|How’s what you do different
context_next: 544147|them|For offense, in addition to points, I look at how many of your field goals were assisted, how valuable those assists were, different types of offensive rebounds, time of possession, etc || 543945|them|In general I use a lot more data that is based on actual player tracking, as appears to approximations based on box score
